description: First attested about 1380. From Middle English abundaunt, habundaunt, aboundant, from Anglo-Norman abundant, from Old French abondant, from Latin abundāns, present participle of abundo (“to overflow, to abound”). Compare abound.

adjectives.description: abundant (comparative more abundant, superlative most abundant)

entries.meaning: Fully sufficient; found in copious supply; in great quantity; overflowing. [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]
examples: Blackberries are abundant in this part of the country in October, so we always make lots of jam.
an abundant selection of carpets to choose from

entries.meaning: Richly supplied; wealthy; possessing in great quantity. [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]
(mathematics) Being an abundant number, i.e. less than the sum of all of its divisors except itself. [First attested in the mid 16th century.]
